Nana always gave this slow, heavy smile. It was hard to tell if it was about lingering anger or some kind of forgiveness. Young Mariam didnâ€™t think about how unfair it was to apologize for how she was born.  

By the time she turned ten, Mariam stopped believing that story. She believed Jalil's version instead. He said he was away but arranged for Nana to go to a hospital in Herat. There, she had a doctor and lay on a clean bed in a bright room. Jalil looked sad when Mariam mentioned the knife.  

Mariam also started to doubt that she made her mom suffer for two whole days.  

"They told me it was all over in under an hour," Jalil said. "You were a good daughter, Mariam jo. Even in birth, you were a good daughter."  

"He wasnâ€™t even there!" Nana shot back. "He was in Takht-e-Safar, riding horses with his precious friends."  

When they told him he had a new daughter, Nana said Jalil just shrugged and kept brushing his horse's mane. He stayed in Takht-e-Safar for another two weeks.  

"The truth is, he didnâ€™t even hold you until you were a month old. And when he did, he just looked down at your long face and handed you back to me."  

Mariam started to doubt that part too. Yes, Jalil admitted he was riding in Takht-e-Safar, but when he heard the news, he didnâ€™t shrug. He hopped on his horse and rode back to Herat. He cradled her in his arms, ran his thumb over her flaky eyebrows, and hummed a lullaby. Mariam didnâ€™t picture him saying her face was long, even though it was.
